case_metadata.title: Case 10111: An American automobile mechanic of thirty-seven

source.journal: Cabot Case Records, Massachusetts General Hospital (Published in Boston Medical and Surgical Journal, later NEJM)
source.doi: N/A for original, but contextually NEJM

past_medical_conditions: Stiffness of the neck and pain in the back of head (1.5 years)
Severe frontal headache, worse toward evening (6 weeks)
Severe muscle pains in legs and back, 'like grippe' (1 week)
Weight loss (Best weight 200 lbs 8 years ago, current 162 lbs)
medications: Collar for neck stiffness (8 months ago, little improvement)

surgical_history.childhood: Broke his leg when a boy
surgical_history.other_procedures: Abscess tapped (neck, 7 months before current admission, May 9)

turn_1.speaker: Dr. Eva Rostova
turn_1.message: Good morning. We're looking at Case 10111 from 1924: a 37-year-old mechanic, Mr. P.H. He presented with a rapid decline—drowsiness, confusion, severe headache, irrationality—over three days. This acute phase was preceded by a week of flu-like symptoms and, importantly, a 1.5-year history of neck stiffness and occipital pain, plus a 6-month dry cough. His history includes pleurisy and an interesting note about 'physiological glycosuria' a year and a half prior, which today would prompt a thorough workup for diabetes or renal glycosuria, not just dismissal after dietary changes. Fifteen months before admission, a neck abscess was drained; it was suspected to be tuberculous, though smears and cultures were negative – a finding not entirely surprising for paucibacillary TB without today's molecular diagnostics like NAAT.
turn_1.intention: Introducing the case, summarizing key history, and highlighting initial points for modern re-evaluation (glycosuria, abscess microbiology).

turn_2.speaker: Dr. Eva Rostova
turn_2.timestamp: Modern Case Review - Physical Exam & Initial Labs
turn_2.message: On exam: febrile, tachycardic, tachypneic. Neurologically, he was clouded with a stiff, painful neck and a positive Kernig's. Fundi showed blurred nasal margins, but no frank papilledema. Lungs had clear signs at the left apex. The urine showed 30-40 leukocytes/hpf – significant pyuria that warrants investigation, though perhaps a secondary issue here. His 'non-protein nitrogen' was 38.1 mg/dL – essentially an early form of a BUN test – indicating mild azotemia, possibly from dehydration or early renal impact.
turn_2.intention: Detailing physical exam findings and initial lab interpretations from a modern perspective.

turn_3.speaker: Dr. Ben Carter
turn_3.message: The CSF from December 9th is almost pathognomonic for TBM, even by their standards, but let's re-evaluate. Opening pressure 300 mm H2O – very high. 280 cells, overwhelmingly lymphocytes (77% lymphs, 20% monos). Protein was sky-high at 200 mg/dL. And the glucose was critically low at 31 mg/dL. This triad is classic. The negative Wassermann is good for ruling out neurosyphilis. The note 'pedicle found' almost certainly refers to a pellicle formation, which we know can occur in TB CSF upon standing and was considered a supportive sign. Their inability to find TB bacilli in it by smear is typical; AFB smear sensitivity in CSF is notoriously low.
turn_3.intention: Critically analyzing CSF findings, explaining historical terms (pedicle/pellicle), and noting limitations of 1924 diagnostics (smear sensitivity).

turn_4.speaker: Dr. Anya Sharma
turn_4.message: The imaging, though basic, is telling. Chest X-ray: 'left lung field distinctly less radiant,' 'dullness most marked at the apex, where there was complete obliteration of the lung markings,' and leftward mediastinal shift with a high left diaphragm. This screams of chronic left upper lobe fibrocavitary TB with significant volume loss. The spine X-rays were deemed 'normal' for the lower cervical/upper dorsal, with only a C1 'abnormality, perhaps due to position.' For his severe, chronic neck stiffness, this is insufficient. Today, an MRI would be mandatory to look for Pott's disease, discitis, or an epidural abscess, which X-ray would easily miss.
turn_4.intention: Interpreting historical X-ray findings with modern understanding and contrasting with current imaging standards (MRI for spinal evaluation).

turn_5.speaker: Dr. Eva Rostova
turn_5.timestamp: Modern Case Review - Second LP & Diagnostic Gaps
turn_5.message: Exactly. The second LP on Dec 14th was similar. The 'numerous paired cocci (contamination?)' is a flag; while likely contamination, we'd ensure rigorous sterile technique and comprehensive cultures today. Their 'Scheer method' for TB bacilli in CSF was negative. Today, Xpert MTB/RIF Ultra on CSF would be our go-to for rapid diagnosis, alongside traditional AFB smear and culture on both liquid and solid media. The yield would be much higher.
turn_5.intention: Discussing the second LP and contrasting outdated diagnostic methods ('Scheer method') with modern, more sensitive molecular tests (Xpert MTB/RIF).

turn_6.speaker: Dr. Ben Carter
turn_6.message: So, the picture is disseminated TB: severe, active pulmonary TB, clearly cavitary in the left apex, leading to tuberculous meningitis. That neck abscess 15 months prior, despite negative microbiology by 1924 standards, was almost certainly tuberculous lymphadenitis or a cold abscess. The negative smears and cultures from it are common in paucibacillary disease; we see that even now, though PCR often picks it up. His pleurisy history is another red flag for prior TB.
turn_6.intention: Formulating a comprehensive diagnosis based on modern understanding of TB pathogenesis and diagnostic challenges with paucibacillary disease.

turn_7.speaker: Dr. Eva Rostova
turn_7.message: He deteriorated and died on Dec 17th. The supportive care they provided—morphia, chloral hydrate—was standard for the era, but obviously, the game-changer would have been anti-tuberculous therapy. If he presented today, we'd initiate empiric four-drug RIPE therapy and adjunctive corticosteroids immediately upon suspicion of TBM, alongside aggressive ICP management. His advanced state at presentation would still carry a poor prognosis, but there'd be a fighting chance.
turn_7.intention: Contrasting 1924 supportive care with modern standard-of-care for TBM (RIPE, corticosteroids, ICP management) and acknowledging prognostic factors.

turn_8.speaker: Dr. Kenji Tanaka
turn_8.message: Dr. Richardson's autopsy confirms it all. Brain: 'thin slightly granular exudate' – classic TBM basal meningitis, confirmed microscopically. Lungs: The left lung had extensive old adhesions and a 5.5 x 4 cm apical cavity packed with purulent material teeming with 'innumerable typical tubercle bacilli' on smear. This was undoubtedly the primary engine of dissemination. Obsolete TB in bronchial glands. The right lung also had a fibrocaseous apical lesion. Interestingly, they found no definitive TB of the cervical spine (axis) at autopsy. This suggests the neck pain and abscess were more likely from severe cervical lymphadenitis (scrofula) rather than direct vertebral osteomyelitis, or any osseous lesion was too subtle for their examination or had perhaps involuted.
turn_8.intention: Reviewing autopsy findings, confirming diagnoses, and offering modern interpretations for discrepancies (e.g., absence of spinal TB at autopsy despite symptoms).

turn_9.speaker: Dr. Ben Carter
turn_9.timestamp: Modern Case Review - Historical Context & Lessons
turn_9.message: This case is a stark reminder of pre-antibiotic era TB. The prolonged history of neck stiffness and cough were clear warning signs that, with modern diagnostics, would likely have led to an earlier diagnosis of pulmonary or extra-pulmonary TB. Dr. Young's 1924 comment about 'sterile abscesses' often being TB is astute; it highlights the challenge of paucibacillary disease confirmation without molecular tools.
turn_9.intention: Reflecting on the case in its historical context and the impact of diagnostic advancements.

turn_10.speaker: Dr. Eva Rostova
turn_10.message: A tragic outcome, but a powerful illustration. The 1924 team correctly suspected TB based on the clinical syndrome and CSF, despite the limitations of their microbiology. The key difference today would be our ability to confirm it much faster and, crucially, to treat it effectively. The case underscores the importance of a high index of suspicion for TB in patients with compatible chronic symptoms and acute neurological decline, and how far our diagnostic and therapeutic capabilities have advanced. Thank you all.
turn_10.intention: Summarizing key learning points and the evolution of medical practice regarding TB.

presentation.chief_complaint_on_admission: Drowsiness, mental clouding, confusion, headache, irrationality, difficulty with words/speech.
presentation.history_of_present_illness: Past 1.5 years: Stiffness of neck and pain in back of head, preventing head turning, character of work changed, sometimes bedridden. 8 months ago: Out-Patient Orthopedic Dept, given collar, little improvement. 6 months ago: Dry hacking cough. 6 weeks before admission: Severe frontal headache, worse toward evening. 1 week before admission: Severe muscle pains in legs and back ('coming down with grippe'), slight chills, wife thought he had fever, unproductive cough, had to give up work. Past 3 days: Increasingly drowsy. Day of admission: Became irrational, forgot words, used incorrect words, thick speech, poor articulation.

physical_exam_on_admission.general: Stalwart man, drowsy and mentally clouded, confusing mouth with eyes, confused when asked to move extremities. Complained of headache.
physical_exam_on_admission.neurological: Sensation could not be determined (lack of response). Mouth held rather tight. Neck stiff and painful on motion. Moved right knee when head was flexed. Knee-jerks slightly increased. Kernig present. Fundi slightly blurred on the nasal margin, both sides, not choked.
physical_exam_on_admission.respiratory: Lungs: Dullness, bronchial breathing and coarse rales at the left apex in front. Slight dullness, bronchial breathing and increased tactile fremitus at the left apex posteriorly. (Dr. Lord also found medium consonating and sonorous rales at left apex).

laboratory_data.findings: Normal amount when recorded. Sp. gr. 1.018, 30-40 leucocytes per high power field.
Blood normal. Wassermann negative. Non-protein nitrogen 38.1 mgm.
Very stringy. No blood or tb.

laboratory_data.pressure: Initial pressure 300 mm.; after withdrawal of 5 c.c. 190 mm.; after 5 c.c. more, 130 mm. Pulse and respiration oscillations present. Jugular compression 100 mm. No block.
laboratory_data.microbiology: Wassermann and gold solution negative. Pedicle found; no tb. seen in it.

laboratory_data.pressure: Hydrodynamics normal. Initial pressure 290; after withdrawal of 5 c.c. 140; after 5 c.c. more 120, after 4 c.c. more 100.
laboratory_data.microbiology: Scheer method, centrifuged with alcohol, no tb. bacilli found. Numerous paired cocci (contamination?). Pedicle, no tb. or other organisms.

laboratory_data.test_group: Neck Abscess Fluid (May 9, 7 months prior to admission)
laboratory_data.microbiology: Smear, broken down pus cells. No tb. or other bacteria. Culture negative.

imaging.area: Lower cervical and upper dorsal spine.
imaging.findings: Normal. Appearance of first cervical vertebra abnormal, perhaps due to position. Two later plates gave no additional information.

imaging.area: Upper dorsal and lower cervical spine.
imaging.findings: No positive evidence of disease in the vertebrae. There was, however, some slight abnormality in the relation of the sixth and seventh dorsal. Request more plates.

Left lung field distinctly less radiant than right. Dullness most marked at the apex, where there was complete obliteration of the lung markings. Heart and mediastinal contents displaced to the left. Diaphragm high on the left and respiratory movements limited.

medications_during_admission: MgSO4 3 iss in the morning (Dec 9 order)
Morphia gr. 1/6 s.c. twice each night p.r.n. (Dec 12 order)
Morphia gr. 1/6 to 1/4 once to every two hours p.r.n. (Dec 14, 15, 16 order)
Chloral hydrate gr. xxx with sodium bromide gr. 50 by rectum at 3 a.m. and 9 p.m. (Dec 16 order)

timeline_key_events.event: Sugar found in urine; placed on diet, lost weight. Later deemed 'physiological glycosuria', gained 10 lbs but not back to normal weight. Onset of neck stiffness and pain in back of head.

timeline_key_events.time: 15 months before admission (Sept 26 of previous year)
timeline_key_events.event: Orthopedic Out-Patient Department visit. Provisional diagnosis of tuberculous abscess of glands of neck and tuberculosis of spine involving axis.
Came to Out-Patient Orthopedic Department for neck pain/stiffness. Told no diagnosis, given collar, little improvement.
X-ray showed lower cervical/upper dorsal spine normal; C1 abnormal (positional?).
Tuberculosis Clinic. Neck abscess tapped; 5 c.c. thick yellow pus. Smear/culture negative for TB/bacteria.
Onset of severe frontal headache, worse toward evening.
Onset of severe muscle pains, slight chills, unproductive cough; stopped work.
Became irrational. Admitted. First lumbar puncture. Dr. Lord's exam noted lung findings.
Second lumbar puncture. Chest and spine X-rays.
Marked delirium, somewhat controlled by morphia, but gradually increasing after second LP.
Headache grew rapidly worse. Patient died.

clinical_diagnosis_from_hospital_record: Chief cause of death, disseminated tuberculosis (spine and lungs).

primary_fatal_lesions: Chronic tuberculosis of bronchial glands and apices of lungs.
Tuberculosis of lungs with cavity formation.
secondary_or_terminal_lesions: Slight hypertrophy and dilatation of the heart.
anatomical_diagnosis_by_dr_richardson_po.autopsy_details_brain: Pia showed a thin slightly granular exudate along upper part of medulla, pons, Sylvian fissures, between frontal lobes. Vessels of Willis, sinuses, middle ears, pineal, pituitary glands negative. Choroid plexus thickened and reddened. Macroscopically suggestive but not well-marked TB of meninges. Microscopically: tuberculous meningitis. Brain tissue a little wet, otherwise negative.
anatomical_diagnosis_by_dr_richardson_po.autopsy_details_pleural_cavities_lungs: No fluid in pleural cavities. Right lung no adhesions. Left lung bound down by old adhesions. Moderate dirty reddish mucus in trachea/bronchi. Some bronchial glands showed obsolete tuberculosis. Apex of right lung: small fibrocaseous pigmented mass (13mm across). Elsewhere spongy, pale red, no definite tubercles. Left lung: pleura over upper third thickened. Apical region: cavity 5.5 by 4 cm containing much purulent material; cover glass from material showed innumerable typical tubercle bacilli. Dilated bronchus led into cavity. Tissue about cavity: scattered tubercles. Short distance below: mass of fibrocaseous material. Little below that: few smaller masses. Scattered about these: smaller and larger tubercles. Lower lobe: only one small fibrocaseous nodule.
anatomical_diagnosis_by_dr_richardson_po.autopsy_details_heart: Weighed 400 grams, slightly enlarged. Valves negative. Little dilatation on the right. Coronaries and vascular apparatus generally negative.
anatomical_diagnosis_by_dr_richardson_po.autopsy_details_spleen: Weighed 125 grams, was soft, but no definite tubercles made out.
anatomical_diagnosis_by_dr_richardson_po.autopsy_details_cervical_spine_axis: No evidence of tuberculosis of the axis or any of the upper cervical vertebrae found.
